summary: This is an FBI Public Affairs News Briefing dated July 24, 2020, covering a wide range of national and international news. It includes sections on protests, counter-terrorism, counter-intelligence, criminal investigations, and other topics. Notably, it contains brief updates on the Ghislaine Maxwell case (federal judges ruling against her gag-order and documents requests) and mentions related to Jeffrey Epstein within the criminal investigations section.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned in the criminal investigations section regarding federal judges ruling against her gag-order and documents requests in her sex abuse case related to Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as the deceased financier whose ex-girlfriend, Ghislaine Maxwell, is facing criminal charges for procuring teenage girls for him to sexually abuse.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over Ghislaine Maxwell's criminal sex abuse case who refused to ban prosecutors or lawyers for alleged victims from commenting publicly.

persons.name: Loretta Preska
persons.context: Judge who authorized the release of new materials related to Ghislaine Maxwell from a 2015 civil lawsuit, including flight logs and deposition testimony.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Frequently mentioned throughout the briefing in various contexts including protests, deployment of federal agents, COVID-19 response, and political commentary.

persons.name: William Barr
persons.context: Mentioned in multiple contexts, including the DOJ inspector general launching probes into use of force in Portland, and being asked for access to Saudi lawsuit records by 9/11 families.

persons.name: Michael Horowitz
persons.context: Justice Department's inspector general who launched probes into alleged use of force by federal agents in Portland and D.C.

persons.name: Ted Wheeler
persons.context: Portland mayor who was tear-gassed by federal agents and criticized by Acting DHS Secretary Wolf for aligning with violent criminals.

persons.name: Chad Wolf
persons.context: Acting Secretary of Homeland Security who defended the deployment of federal agents to Portland and stated they do not need an invitation from local officials.

persons.name: Lori Lightfoot
persons.context: Chicago mayor who discussed plans with President Trump to deploy federal agents to Chicago and suggested the deployments target Democratic mayors.

persons.name: Joe Biden
persons.context: Mentioned in various political contexts, including criticism for labeling Trump the first racist president and in relation to packets sent by a Ukrainian lawmaker.

persons.name: Kayla Mueller
persons.context: American aid worker kidnapped and murdered by ISIS; mentioned in an interview with British ISIS members who admitted to holding Americans captive.

persons.name: John Durham
persons.context: Leading a criminal inquiry into the Russia investigation; KT McFarland suggested he would issue indictments in the coming months.

persons.name: Michael Cohen
persons.context: Released from prison after a judge found he was retaliated against for writing a book about President Trump.

persons.name: Alvin K. Hellerstein
persons.context: Judge who ordered Michael Cohen released from prison, ruling his First Amendment rights were violated.

persons.name: Mike Pompeo
persons.context: Mentioned in various international news contexts, including urging the Chinese people to change the Communist Party and discussing coronavirus with Putin.

persons.name: Rudy Giuliani
persons.context: Mentioned in relation to packets on Biden sent to Trump allies by a Ukrainian lawmaker and his outreach to Pompeo regarding Marie Yovanovitch.

persons.name: Marie Yovanovitch
persons.context: Former ambassador whose ouster was linked to Rudy Giuliani's outreach to Pompeo.

persons.name: Alex Jones
persons.context: Mentioned in a case where the Connecticut Supreme Court upheld sanctions against him in a Sandy Hook defamation lawsuit.

connections.description: Maxwell is described as Epstein's ex-girlfriend who is accused of procuring teenage girls for him to sexually abuse.
President Trump and Attorney General Barr are connected through the administration's law enforcement and political actions discussed throughout the briefing.
President Trump and Secretary of State Pompeo are connected through foreign policy actions and statements reported in the briefing.
Giuliani's outreach to Pompeo is mentioned in the context of efforts to discredit Ambassador Marie Yovanovitch.
British ISIS members admitted to holding Kayla Mueller and other Americans captive before their deaths.

events.title: Judges Rule in Maxwell Case
events.description: Federal judges rule against Ghislaine Maxwell's gag-order request and authorize the release of documents from a 2015 civil lawsuit, including Epstein flight logs.

events.title: Michael Cohen Released
events.description: Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein orders Michael Cohen released from prison, ruling his return to prison was retaliatory for writing a book about President Trump.

events.title: Trump Cancels RNC Jacksonville Events
events.description: President Trump cancels the Republican National Convention events in Jacksonville, Florida, citing coronavirus concerns.

events.title: US COVID-19 Cases Surpass 4 Million
events.description: The United States surpasses 4 million confirmed coronavirus cases, with a rapid increase in infections.

events.title: Portland Protests and Federal Response
events.description: Continued protests in Portland with federal agent involvement; a judge grants a restraining order against federal agents arresting journalists and legal observers.

events.title: FBI Briefing of Candidate Trump
events.description: Newly declassified document shows FBI agents who had just opened the Russia investigation led President Trump's first intelligence briefing as a candidate.

locations: Brooklyn, New York (federal jail where Ghislaine Maxwell is held)
Palm Beach, Florida (where Epstein had a home)
Santa Monica, California (where Bulger and Greig were captured)
keyFacts: Federal judges ruled against Ghislaine Maxwell's requests for a gag order and for documents to remain sealed; documents from a 2015 civil lawsuit were ordered released, including Jeffrey Epstein's flight logs.
The FBI News Briefing is a daily compilation of news from various sources, not an internal FBI investigative document.
The document shows the wide range of issues monitored by the FBI's Public Affairs office, including criminal cases, counter-terrorism, and political events.
The briefing includes an update on the Michael Cohen case, where a judge found he was retaliated against for writing a book about President Trump and ordered his release.
The document reflects the political and social climate of July 2020, including protests, the COVID-19 pandemic, and tensions with China.
